claim: The trails left in the sky by aircraft are water-based.

supporting.text: Aircraft contrails are composed primarily of water vapor that condenses into ice crystals at high altitudes.

attacks.text: Aircraft contrails are composed primarily of water vapor that condenses into ice crystals at high altitudes.
Contrails can also contain soot and other pollutants from aircraft engines, not just water vapor.
The soot and pollutants are present in trace amounts and do not change the fact that contrails are primarily water-based.
Persistent contrails can contribute to cirrus cloud formation, which may have climate impacts beyond simple water vapor.
While persistent contrails may affect climate, their composition remains predominantly water ice, supporting the original claim.

supporting.text: The visible trails behind aircraft are formed when hot exhaust gases mix with cold air, leading to condensation and freezing of water vapor.

attacks.text: The visible trails behind aircraft are formed when hot exhaust gases mix with cold air, leading to condensation and freezing of water vapor.
Some trails contain particulate matter from engine emissions, not just water vapor.
The particulate matter is a minor component; the primary composition remains water-based.
Persistent contrails can indicate the presence of ice crystals or other non-water substances.
Ice crystals are still a form of water, supporting the claim that trails are water-based.

supporting.text: Scientific studies confirm that contrails consist of ice particles formed from the water content in aircraft engine exhaust.

attacks.text: Scientific studies confirm that contrails consist of ice particles formed from the water content in aircraft engine exhaust.
Some contrails persist and spread, forming artificial cirrus clouds, which suggests they may contain other substances beyond just water.
The persistence of contrails is primarily due to atmospheric conditions like humidity and temperature, not additional substances.
Military aircraft have been observed releasing materials for radar disruption, which could be mistaken for contrails.
Radar disruption materials are distinct in composition and behavior from contrails, and their use is rare and situational.

supporting.text: Meteorological research classifies contrails as a type of cirrus cloud, which are made of ice crystals derived from water vapor.

attacks.text: Meteorological research classifies contrails as a type of cirrus cloud, which are made of ice crystals derived from water vapor.
Contrails can also contain other byproducts of jet fuel combustion, such as soot and sulfur compounds, not just water vapor.
The primary component of contrails is still water vapor, as the combustion of hydrocarbons in jet fuel produces water as a major byproduct.
Persistent contrails can spread and contribute to artificial cloud cover, which may have different properties than natural cirrus clouds.
Even when spreading, persistent contrails remain composed of ice crystals, consistent with natural cirrus cloud composition.

supporting.text: Aircraft fuel combustion produces water vapor as a byproduct, which is the primary component of contrails.

attacks.text: Aircraft fuel combustion produces water vapor as a byproduct, which is the primary component of contrails.
Contrails also contain other combustion byproducts like soot and sulfur compounds, not just water vapor.
The proportion of non-water components in contrails is negligible compared to the water vapor content.
Persistent contrails can contribute to cirrus cloud formation, which affects climate, showing they are not purely water-based.
The climate impact is due to the water vapor's physical state and distribution, not chemical composition.
